paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on genetic variants in the KCNH2 gene related to Short QT Syndrome, including penetrance data.

individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patient P1 experienced syncope at age 25 and was diagnosed with SQTS at age 28.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Diagnosed with SQTS after presenting with arrhythmias.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patient P2 was diagnosed with SQTS at age 31 after presenting with arrhythmias.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Diagnosed with SQTS with no prior symptoms.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patient P3 was diagnosed with SQTS at age 29 with no prior symptoms.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Carrier of the variant but asymptomatic.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patient P4 is a carrier of the N588K variant but remains asymptomatic.

functional_data.summary: The N588K mutation in KCNH2 leads to gain-of-function effects, resulting in shortened action potentials.

variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on functional assays and family segregation.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the importance of the KCNH2 gene in SQTS.
key_quotes: The N588K mutation in KCNH2 is associated with Short QT Syndrome.
Patient P1 experienced syncope at age 25 and was diagnosed with SQTS at age 28.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text.
